questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bleeding from the nipple of her right breast for 3 months. There is no bleeding from the other breast. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and lasts for 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 53 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Breast examination shows bleeding of the right breast on application of pressure with no palpable mass. The left breast shows no abnormalities. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Ultrasonography shows a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma may also manifest with bloody nipple discharge. Furthermore, a positive family history increases the risk of developing breast cancer. However, it most commonly manifests with a mass on palpation, and ultrasound would show a poorly circumscribed mass with microcalcifications.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenomas are uncommon after the age of 40 and do not present with nipple discharge. Instead, a palpable mass that slips under the palpating hand can usually be felt. Ultrasonography typically shows a well-circumscribed, homogenous, hypoechoic mass with or without a hyperechogenic rim (pseudocapsule) and coarse calcifications.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with Paget disease of the breast may present with bloody discharge from the nipple, but the nipple and areola would appear erythematous, fissured, cracked, and/or ulcerated. Ultrasonographic findings are usually nonspecific with heterogenous, hypoechoic regions, skin thickening, and/or dilated ducts.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors typically manifest as large, painless breast masses. On ultrasound, the tumor appears sharply demarcated from the surrounding breast tissue, which appears compressed and distorted, unlike in this patient. The cysts within the tumor give rise to characteristic slit-like hypoechoic regions.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with papillary carcinoma of the breast may present with bloody discharge from the nipple and an intraductal mass on ultrasound. However, papillary carcinoma of the breast usually occurs in postmenopausal women, with a peak incidence in the seventh decade.

F) CORRECT:

Solitary intraductal papillomas typically manifest with unilateral bloody nipple discharge. Although physical exam may reveal a palpable breast tumor close to or behind the nipple, intraductal papillomas may not be palpable. The absence of associated breast skin changes or axillary lymphadenopathy and the ultrasound finding of a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass support the diagnosis.

Although these lesions are typically benign, they may harbor areas of atypical hyperplasia or DCIS. Therefore, a core needle biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and rule out malignancy. Impalpable tumors, as seen in this patient, should be visualized via ductogram first. Subsequent excision of the affected duct is indicated in all patients.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast

A well-defined solitary mass (blue overlay) is seen within a dilated mammary duct.

The main differential diagnoses are intraductal papilloma, ductal carcinoma (especially papillary carcinoma), and inspissated secretions. Secretions do not show vascularity on color Doppler. Intraductal papilloma may show a vascular stalk. Ductal carcinoma cannot always be reliably distinguished from intraductal papilloma by ultrasound.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a mass in the left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. During this period, the mass has not increased in size and the patient has had no pain. Three months ago, she hit her left chest against the closet door and it was painful for a day. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm well-defined, rubbery, nontender mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumors may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. This 29-year-old woman lacks the characteristic symptoms of phyllodes tumor, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papillomas most commonly manifest with unilateral bloody nipple discharge and are typically located in the central area of the breast (because ductal tissue is more concentrated there) rather than the upper outer quadrant. Furthermore, they are more common in older patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes of the breast are the most common benign lesions of the breast and typically manifest with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On exam, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

A nontender, well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency in a 29-year-old woman with no mastalgia, no changes in the skin over the breast, nor axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Fibroadenomas should be closely monitored with clinical breast examinations and imaging (ultrasound and/or mammogram). Ultrasound-guided biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy if lesions increase in size or have atypical imaging findings (e.g., calcifications).

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient has none of the findings of Paget disease of the breast, such as nipple and areola erythema, scaly rash, pruritus, nipple discharge, or retraction, it is an unlikely diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma is usually associated with suspicious characteristics, including: age > 35 years, positive family history, skin changes, axillary adenopathy, asymmetry, and a firm, rigid mass with irregular borders. None of these features are present in this patient, meaning that carcinoma is unlikely. Nevertheless, this patient should undergo mammography to rule out any potential suspicious radiological signs.

G) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer is characterized by skin changes, specifically breast erythema, dimpling, and diffuse swelling that is similar in appearance to the peel of an orange (often termed “peau d'orange”). These symptoms are not present in this patient.

H) INCORRECT:

Although patients with fat necrosis of the breast commonly report a history of breast trauma, this condition typically manifests as a firm, periareolar mass with irregular borders that may have an overlying area of skin thickening or retraction. This patient's well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency makes a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast is likely to show a well-defined mass with homogeneous hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma causes single or multiple, sometimes palpable breast lesions that are associated with serous or bloody nipple discharge in 60–80% of cases. This patient's lack of discharge makes the diagnosis less likely. In addition, the biopsy findings rule out intraductal papilloma, which would show a central, branching, fibrovascular core with surrounding myoepithelial and epithelial cells.

B) CORRECT:

A large (> 3 cm), rapidly growing breast mass with no associated axillary lymphadenopathy in combination with a lobular appearance on mammography raises suspicion for a phyllodes tumor. Phyllodes tumors are rare (< 1% of all breast tumors) and typically manifest with a painless breast lump, which can make it difficult to differentiate this tumor from more common benign breast tumors (e.g., fibroadenoma). Phyllodes tumors may even appear similar to fibroadenoma on imaging. A core needle biopsy is required to definitively diagnose phyllodes tumor and to rule out malignancy. (See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.)

Although most phyllodes tumors are benign, ∼ 25% of cases are malignant. Surgical excision with wide margins is required. Surgery for patients with benign phyllodes tumors is usually curative, although local recurrence can occur, which often warrants total mastectomy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a breast tissue specimen (H&E stain; low magnification)

A hypercellular stroma (example indicated by blue overlay) is visible in the right half of the image. Several clefts or slit-like spaces (examples indicated by black dashed line) lined by darker stained epithelial cells are visible within the stroma, giving it a leaf-like appearance. These are characteristic features of a phyllodes tumor.

Normal breast tissue is visible in the left half of the image.

C) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast presents with an erythematous and scaly rash affecting the nipple and areola, accompanied by pruritus, burning, nipple retraction, and possibly, blood-tinged nipple discharge. Although the underlying etiology of Paget disease of the breast (ductal carcinoma) may cause a palpable breast mass, this patient's breast exam has no evidence of Paget disease, given the absence of skin or nipple changes.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenomas are the most common breast tumors in women < 35 years old, and usually manifest as a solitary, nontender, mobile mass, very similar to this patient's lesion. However, fibroadenomas are less common in women > 35 years and typically have “popcorn” calcifications on mammography. Biopsy of fibroadenoma would show benign hyperplastic stroma encapsulating ductal tissue. Additionally, the rapid growth and size of this patient's tumor are not common features of fibroadenoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic breast disease is the most common benign condition of the breast and commonly causes a palpable breast mass. However, fibrocystic breast lesions are typically associated with mastalgia, cyclic pain with menses, and clear/white nipple discharge, none of which are present in this case. On mammogram, fibrocystic disease would typically show focal regions of thick parenchyma and/or cysts. Additionally, fibrocystic disease is not associated with papillary projections on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue affected by fibrocystic disease

Cystic ducts (black dashed lines) and fibrosis of mammary tissue, i.e., increased collagen fibers in the stroma (green overlay), are visible. Apocrine metaplasia can also be seen in association with the fibrocystic changes (white overlay). For comparison, the regular terminal duct lobular unit of the breast is visible on the right (white dashed lines).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

F) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common form of breast cancer and can manifest as a painless breast mass. Although malignancy should always be considered in patients with breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, invasive ductal carcinoma is more likely to manifest with skin changes (retraction, dimpling, edema), nipple retraction, bloody nipple discharge, and/or lymphadenopathy. Moreover, mammogram typically shows microcalcifications and spiculations while biopsy shows malignant cells in the ducts with microcalcifications and stromal invasion.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of biopsy specimen (H&E stain; low magnification) from a mobile breast lump in 64-year-old female patient

Main image: At low magnification, a dense irregular mass (purple/pink) with poorly circumscribed borders can be seen infiltrating the mature adipose tissue of the breast (white). The mass is composed of disorganized tubular formations of the carcinoma (dark blue/basophilic staining) and surrounding collagenous connective tissue (pink/eosinophilic staining; also known as “desmoplastic stroma”).

Top right inset: very low magnification overview indicating the location of the main image on the specimen

G) INCORRECT:

Invasive lobular carcinoma accounts for 10–15% of breast cancers and may manifest as a painless breast nodule. Although malignancy should always be considered in breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, invasive lobular carcinoma is associated with skin changes (retraction, dimpling, edema), nipple retraction, bloody nipple discharge, and/or lymphadenopathy. Moreover, mammogram typically shows microcalcifications and spicules, and biopsy shows malignant cells in lobules and monomorphic cells in single rows.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a breast tumor tissue specimen (H&E stain; 40x magnification)

Infiltrating malignant cells can be seen as single cells, narrow chords (examples indicated by green overlay), and characteristic single-file formations (examples indicated by blue overlay). The tumor cells are seen growing between distorted ductuli (D) and lobuli (L), surrounded by conspicuously pale connective tissue. There is no tubule formation of the tumor (as is commonly seen in other types of adenocarcinomas of the breast).

This is the typical appearance of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Click on the microscope icon (at the top) to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.
questions.hint: A leaf-like architecture of papillary projections of epithelium-lined stroma is characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painful mass in her left breast for 2 weeks. She has no fevers or chills. She has not noticed any changes in the right breast. She has no history of serious illness. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a palpable, mobile, tender mass in the left upper quadrant of the breast. Ultrasound shows a 1.75-cm, well-circumscribed anechoic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement. The patient says that she is very concerned that she may have breast cancer and would like further diagnostic testing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: MRI scan of the left breast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Simple breast cysts are almost always benign and further diagnostic steps are not routinely required. However, patients who are symptomatic and/or concerned about breast cancer may undergo fine-needle aspiration, which can be either diagnostic, therapeutic, or both (i.e., aspiration of clear, nonbloody fluid that results in complete resolution of the lesion confirms the diagnosis of a simple cyst; fluid removal provides symptom relief). The patient should be reevaluated for potential recurrence.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast

An oval lesion with smooth, thin and regularly shaped walls is visible (green overlay). Since the lesion presents anechoic, it can be concluded that it is filled with fluid and contains no solid areas.

These findings are consistent with a benign breast cyst.

B) INCORRECT:

A mammogram is indicated to evaluate a palpable breast mass in patients > 30 years of age. In younger patients, however, breast tissue is hypersensitive to radiation exposure and very dense, thus limiting the utility of mammography. In addition, this patient's ultrasound findings suggest a simple cyst, rendering a mammogram dispensable.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging of the breast is indicated in patients with inconclusive mammographic or ultrasound findings and in women with a high risk of breast cancer (e.g., BRCA mutation carriers). However, it is not routinely used in the evaluation of palpable breast lesions because it is expensive and rarely provides additional useful information. In this patient, ultrasonography confirmed a cystic mass, so an MRI is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up is an appropriate approach for patients with an asymptomatic or only mildly symptomatic breast cyst on ultrasound. However, further diagnostic and therapeutic steps should be performed if the patient is concerned about symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy is indicated only in few patients with suspicious breast lesions, e.g., when the mass is not accessible by core needle biopsy (CNB) or CNB results are inconclusive. This patient's findings on ultrasound are most consistent with a benign breast cyst that does not require excision.

F) INCORRECT:

Core needle biopsy is indicated in patients with a suspicious solid breast mass on ultrasound or mammography and those with malignant features on fine needle aspiration (e.g., a mass that does not completely resolve upon aspiration). This patient's ultrasound findings, however, suggest a benign breast cyst.
questions.hint: A well-circumscribed anechoic mass with posterior acoustic enhancement in a premenopausal woman suggests a simple breast cyst.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling of her right breast for the past 4 days. She also reports malaise and some pain with breastfeeding. Over the past 2 days, she has been using over-the-counter analgesics and applying cabbage leaves and cooling pads on her breast without improvement of her symptoms. Three weeks ago, she delivered a healthy 3500-g (7.7-lb) girl. She has no history of serious illness. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 55 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a tender, firm, swollen, erythematous right breast. Examination of the left breast shows no abnormalities. In addition to continuing cold compresses and analgesic therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue breastfeeding with the right breast and initiate dicloxacillin therapy
Continue breastfeeding with the right breast and initiate trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy
Continue breastfeeding with the right breast
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast and perform ultrasonography
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast and perform surgical drainage
Stop breastfeeding with the right breast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Mastitis may arise in the postpartum period as nipple fissures (from breastfeeding) facilitate the entry of bacteria and stagnant milk (due to overproduction or insufficient drainage) creates favorable conditions for bacterial growth within the lactiferous ducts. Initially, conservative treatment with analgesia and cold compresses is indicated. If there is no improvement within 12–24 hours of conservative treatment, an oral antibiotic that has strong activity against Staphylococcus aureus (the most common causative pathogen) and is safe during breastfeeding (e.g., dicloxacillin, cephalexin) is indicated. Mothers should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding with the affected breast in order to empty milk reserves and prevent a breast abscess from developing.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) can be used to treat mastitis caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). However, due to the risk of kernicterus in the newborn, TMP/SMX should be avoided if possible. If initial treatment with the appropriate therapy is not effective and breast milk culture shows MRSA, clindamycin or TMP/SMX is the preferred alternative treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Continued breastfeeding with conservative treatment (cold compresses and analgesic therapy) is appropriate for the management of breast engorgement, which can manifest with tenderness, firmness, and fullness of the breast. However, breast engorgement is not associated with erythema and fever and usually occurs 3–5 days postpartum. This patient's fever and persistent symptoms lasting > 24 hours indicate severe mastitis, for which conservative treatment alone is insufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with mastitis, additional workup (e.g., imaging, breast milk cultures) are not routinely indicated. Ultrasonography is performed if the patient does not respond to empiric antibiotic therapy within 48–72 hours or if a breast abscess is suspected (the presence of a tender, fluctuant mass).

Breast imaging is also performed if breast cancer is suspected. Although the patient has a family history of breast cancer, and some breast carcinomas can manifest with erythema (Paget disease of the breast, inflammatory breast cancer), the patient does not present with features suggestive of those conditions such as a scaly rash, nipple retraction, or blood-tinged nipple discharge. Fever, pain with breastfeeding, and the acute nature of this patient's illness in the puerperal period are not consistent with breast cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

In the event the patient develops a tender, fluctuant mass suggestive of a breast abscess, surgical drainage is required. However, this patient shows no such finding and should instead receive treatment for mastitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Nursing mothers with mastitis should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding with both breasts every 2–3 hours to facilitate breast emptying, thereby reducing the risk of developing a breast abscess.
questions.hint: This nursing mother presents with a tender, firm, swollen, erythematous breast and fever 3 weeks after giving birth. These findings are suggestive of mastitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician 10 days after noticing a mass in her left breast while bathing. She is concerned that it is breast cancer because her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer 3 years ago at 61 years of age. Menopause occurred 6 months ago. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She took an oral contraceptive for 20 years. Current medications include hormone replacement therapy and a calcium supplement. On examination, a 2.5-cm, hard, nontender mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Examination of the right breast and axillae shows no abnormalities. Mammography shows an irregular mass with microcalcifications and oil cysts. A core biopsy specimen shows foam cells and multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with breast cancer, neoadjuvant chemotherapy can reduce the size of the tumor before surgery to allow for greater preservation of normal tissue (e.g., by performing a lumpectomy instead of mastectomy). This patient, however, most likely has fat necrosis of the breast and, therefore, chemotherapy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Trastuzumab is an adjuvant therapy for biopsy-proven ERBB2+ breast cancer. Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Furthermore, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.

C) CORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast is a benign breast condition most commonly caused by trauma to the breast. Patients may present with examination and radiological findings that mimic malignancy (e.g., irregular borders, skin retraction), and biopsy is typically performed to confirm the diagnosis. Fat necrosis does not increase the risk of breast cancer and, therefore, reassurance and follow-up in accordance with breast cancer screening guidelines is appropriate. If fat necrosis causes significant discomfort, pain, or distortion of the breast, surgery may be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumpectomy with axillary staging (i.e., sentinel lymph node biopsy) is a treatment option for patients with a solitary malignant tumor localized to one breast quadrant. Patients who undergo lumpectomy usually require adjuvant radiation to reduce the risk of recurrence. This patient, however, most likely has fat necrosis of the breast and, therefore, lumpectomy with axillary staging is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Anastrozole is an adjuvant therapy for postmenopausal women with biopsy-proven, hormone-receptor-sensitive breast cancer. Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Also, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Tamoxifen is an adjuvant therapy for women with biopsy-proven, hormone-receptor-sensitive breast cancer. Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Also, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.

G) INCORRECT:

Modified radical mastectomy is indicated for patients with biopsy-proven breast cancer that has spread to the axillary lymph nodes. This patient, however, most likely has fat necrosis of the breast and, therefore, mastectomy is not indicated.

H) INCORRECT:

Wide excision is indicated for phyllodes tumors because of their high rate of recurrence and potential for malignancy. A core biopsy specimen of a phyllodes tumor would show a leaf-like structure with papillary projections of epithelium-lined stroma, not foam cells and giant cells, the presence of which indicates fat necrosis of the breast. Excision may sometimes be considered in patients with fat necrosis of the breast who develop significant pain, discomfort, or distortion of the breast.

I) INCORRECT:

Simple mastectomy is indicated for patients with biopsy-proven breast cancer without spread to the axillary lymph nodes, and in those who do not meet criteria for breast-conserving surgery (e.g., contraindications to adjuvant radiation, > 1 tumor in separate breast quadrant). Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Also, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.
questions.hint: The presence of oil cysts on mammography suggests fat necrosis of the breast. Foam cells and multinucleated giant cells on biopsy confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of small quantities of intermittent, blood-tinged discharge from her left nipple. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. Her last menstrual period was 12 days ago. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination shows scant serosanguinous fluid expressible from the left nipple. There is no palpable breast mass or axillary lymphadenopathy. Examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prolactin levels (hyperprolactinemia) in premenopausal women can cause galactorrhea (bilateral nonbloody discharge). Common causes of physiological hyperprolactinemia include pregnancy and emotional stress, while those of pathological hyperprolactinemia include pituitary adenoma (manifests with headaches and bitemporal hemianopsia) or intake of certain drugs (e.g., antipsychotics, SSRIs). This patient has no history to suggest either physiological or pathological hyperprolactinemia and presents with unilateral sanguineous nipple discharge, which warrants a different workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Ductography is indicated in patients who present with pathological nipple discharge if other imaging is inconclusive or shows features suspicious of malignancy (e.g., ductal irregularity). Ductography is not routinely indicated for the evaluation of pathological nipple discharge because it is expensive, exposes the patient to radiation, and is technically difficult to perform. Also, most causes of nipple discharge in women < 30 years of age are benign.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with red flags for nipple discharge should be evaluated with imaging studies for lactiferous duct pathologies. Patients > 30 years of age should undergo ultrasonography AND diagnostic mammography to detect signs of ductal abnormalities (e.g., dilated ducts, ductal mass/nodule). For patients < 30 years of age, subareolar breast ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality; because breast tissue density is higher in this age group, a mammogram is less effective at detecting small lesions. Also, there is no ionizing radiation exposure associated with ultrasound imaging, unlike during a mammogram. If imaging reveals signs of malignancy, a biopsy of the lesion is indicated. Nonmilky nipple discharge is most commonly caused by benign conditions, such as intraductal papilloma or ductal ectasia, but may also be a sign of underlying malignancy (e.g., ductal carcinoma in situ).

In nonpregnant patients with bilateral, milky (nonbloody) nipple discharge (galactorrhea), laboratory assessment with measurement of serum prolactin levels is the first diagnostic step to evaluate for hyperprolactinemia.
Image Description:

DBT: digital breast tomosynthesis
TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone

D) INCORRECT:

An image-guided biopsy can be performed in the diagnostic workup of patients with unilateral, nonmilky nipple discharge. However, this diagnostic step is reserved for those with evidence of malignancy (e.g., irregularity of a duct wall) on prior imaging studies.

E) INCORRECT:

Cytological examination of nipple discharge is not recommended because of its low sensitivity in detecting malignancy, high false-negative rates (a negative cytology does not definitively rule out malignancy), and low-cost effectiveness. In addition, cytology, if positive, does not help localize the lesion nor differentiate between an in situ and invasive carcinoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Mammography is recommended for the evaluation of focal breast findings (e.g., unilateral nipple discharge) in women > 30 years of age. However, this imaging modality is not recommended as the first-line diagnostic test in patients < 30 years of age. Breast tissue is very dense in this group, limiting the efficacy of mammograms to detect small lesions. Furthermore, mammography exposes the patient to ionizing radiation. Finally, the incidence of breast cancer in women < 30 years of age is low. Another diagnostic test for the evaluation of nipple discharge is, therefore, more appropriate in this patient group.

G) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is indicated in patients with nipple discharge that is consistent with normoprolactinemic galactorrhea. This condition manifests with bilateral milky discharge and normal prolactin levels. This patient, however, presents with unilateral, nonmilky nipple discharge, which requires further investigation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with red flags for nipple discharge (unilateral, spontaneous, and serosanguineous nipple discharge).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a left breast mass that she noticed 4 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 6-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic breast disease is the most common benign condition of the breast and commonly causes a palpable breast mass. However, fibrocystic breast lesions are typically associated with mastalgia, cyclic pain with menses, and clear/white nipple discharge, none of which are present in this case. On mammogram, fibrocystic disease would typically show focal regions of thick parenchyma and/or cysts. In addition, fibrocystic disease is not associated with a leaf-like appearance and papillary projections on biopsy.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; A. mediolateral oblique (MLO) view; B. magnification view) of a patient with biopsy-proven fibrocystic disease

Multiple coarse heterogeneous (examples indicated by green arrowheads) and fine pleomorphic calcifications (examples indicated by red arrowheads) are segmentally distributed in the breast.

The main descriptors of breast calcifications (examples indicated by green circle) on mammography are morphology and distribution. Both descriptors are considered in the evaluation of cancer risk and in the determination of need for further imaging or biopsy. Mammographic findings are categorized according to the American College of Radiology (ACR) Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS).

B) INCORRECT:

Comedocarcinoma is a breast tumor associated with an increased risk of malignancy. It is a type of ductal carcinoma in situ with rapid intraductal proliferation of cells that leads to necrosis and cellular debris within the ducts. On microscopic examination, comedocarcinoma is characterized by solid growth of large, pleomorphic, high-grade cells with central expansile necrosis, mitotic figures, periductal inflammation and fibrosis, and coarse microcalcifications. This patient's biopsy is inconsistent with comedocarcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common form of breast cancer and can present as a painless breast mass. Although malignancy should always be considered in patients with breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, infiltrating ductal carcinoma is more likely to appear with associated skin changes (retraction, dimpling, edema), nipple retraction, and/or bloody nipple discharge. Also, infiltrating ductal carcinoma typically has microcalcifications and spiculations on mammogram and would show malignant cells in the ducts with microcalcifications and stromal invasion on biopsy. This patient's benign mammogram and biopsy rule out this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years old, and usually presents as a solitary, nontender, mobile mass, very similar to this patient's lesion. However, fibroadenoma is less common in women > 35 years and typically has “popcorn” calcifications on mammography. Biopsy of fibroadenoma would show benign hyperplastic stroma encapsulating ductal tissue. In addition, the rapid growth and size of this patient's tumor are not common features of fibroadenoma.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

A large (> 3 cm), rapidly growing (i.e., progression over days-weeks) breast mass raises suspicion for phyllodes tumor. Phyllodes tumors are rare (< 1% of all breast tumors) and typically present as a painless breast lump, which can make differentiation from more common benign breast tumors (e.g., fibroadenoma) difficult. Phyllodes tumors may even appear similar to fibroadenoma on imaging. Therefore, biopsy is required to definitively diagnose phyllodes tumor; biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope, for which the tumor is named.

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.

F) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma causes single or multiple, sometimes palpable breast lesions that are associated with serous or bloody nipple discharge in 60–80% of cases. This patient's lack of discharge makes the diagnosis less likely. In addition, the biopsy findings rule out intraductal papilloma, which would show a central, branching, fibrovascular core with surrounding myoepithelial and epithelial cells.

G) INCORRECT:

Invasive lobular carcinoma causes 10–15% of breast cancers and can present as a painless breast nodule. Although malignancy should always be considered in breast masses, especially in middle-aged women, infiltrating lobular carcinoma would be more likely if there were associated skin changes (retraction, dimpling, edema), nipple retraction, or bloody nipple discharge. Also, infiltrating lobular carcinoma typically has microcalcification and spiculations on mammogram and would show malignant cells in lobules and monomorphic cells in single rows (often referred to as 'single file' pattern) on biopsy. This patient's benign mammogram and biopsy rule out this diagnosis.
questions.hint: This 48-year-old woman has a rapidly growing 6-cm breast mass without any mastalgia, skin/nipple changes, or lymphadenopathy, indicating a benign condition. The mammogram also suggests a benign lesion (no spiculations or microcalcifications), and the biopsy confirms the diagnosis, showing a leaf-like microarchitecture.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman at 17-weeks gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of a painless mass in the right breast for the last 3 weeks that has not increased in size. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm rubbery, mobile mass that is nontender in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. A biopsy of the mass shows rounded contour with overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The presence of a solid, painless, mobile mass in a 33-year-old pregnant woman without any mastalgia, changes in skin over the breast, or axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma, the most common breast tumor (although benign) in women < 35 years of age. This pregnant patient's elevated estrogen levels have likely contributed to the mass appearance. A biopsy showing overgrowth of fibrous and glandular tissue confirms the diagnosis.

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

B) INCORRECT:

An intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of unilateral bloody nipple discharge (not present in this patient). It is also associated with older patients and is typically located in the central area of the breast (because ductal tissue is more concentrated there) and not in the upper outer quadrant, making it an unlikely diagnosis. Biopsy varies shows fibrovascular tissues surrounded by epithelial cells within lactiferous ducts.

C) INCORRECT:

Breasts increase in size and may be tender during pregnancy, but masses are not normal and should be evaluated further. However, hormone-responsive masses can increase in size during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic change of the breast is the most common benign lesion of the breast and typically presents with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On examination, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient, making it an unlikely diagnosis. Biopsy findings vary and include stromal fibrosis, cysts, papillary apocrine changes, and mild epithelial hyperplasia or calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis presents as an area of ecchymosis, erythema, and/or skin thickening following trauma to the breast, none of which are present in this patient. Biopsy would show fat necrosis with foam cells, multinucleated giant cells, hemosiderin deposition, and/or chronic inflammation.

F) INCORRECT:

Unlike in this patient, phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), grow at a fast rate, and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumor may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. A biopsy would show leaf-like architecture with papillary projection of epithelium-lined stroma.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast would likely show a well-defined mass with generally uniform hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician a week after noticing a lump in her left breast. Three months ago, she was discharged from the hospital after treatment of multiple injuries sustained in a motor vehicle collision. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother died of ovarian cancer. Examination shows a 2.5-cm, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Mammography shows a circumscribed radiolucent lesion with a rim of peripheral calcification. A photomicrograph of tissue from a biopsy of the mass is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the breast swelling?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast (Mondor disease) can occur secondary to trauma. However, it would manifest as a tender, palpable superficial cord on the anterolateral surface of the breast and not as the painless lump seen here. Mammography, though not typically done in Mondor disease, would show a superficial tubular hypodense lesion. A biopsy would show a thrombosed vein and acute inflammatory infiltrate, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of estrogen receptors is the underlying cause for the development of fibroadenoma, fibrocystic breast changes, and ER-positive breast cancer. All three of these conditions may present with a painless breast lump and calcifications on mammography, as seen in this patient. However, a fibroadenoma would show proliferation of glandular and stromal tissue on histopathology, while fibrocystic breast changes often cause nipple discharge, show numerous small cysts on mammography, and appear as proliferation of small ductules and acini in lobules on histopathology. Breast cancer is also unlikely because it would appear as an ill-defined mass with irregular microcalcifications on mammography, and cells with features of malignant transformation (e.g., hyperchromatism, mitotic figures) in the ducts or lobules on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective DNA repair is the underlying cause of hereditary breast cancer syndromes (e.g., BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, Lynch syndrome). Breast cancer can manifest as a painless breast lump and this patient has a high risk of developing breast cancer based on her age and family history of ovarian cancer. However, breast cancer would typically appear on mammography as an ill-defined mass with irregular microcalcifications and not as the circumscribed radiolucent lesion seen here. Moreover, cells with features of malignant transformation (e.g., hyperchromatism, mitotic figures, nuclear pleomorphism) would have been present in the ducts or lobules on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a surgical sample of breast tissue (H&E stain, low magnification)

An area of sclerosis (light purple) is visible in the center of the invasive ductal carcinoma (dark purple).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of lactiferous ducts can result in a palpable breast lump due to breast abscess, a complication of mastitis. Breast abscess typically manifests as a tender breast lump with signs of inflammation (erythema, warmth, and tenderness) in lactating women. This patient's lump, however, is nontender, and she is not lactating. Mammography of breast abscess, though not typically performed, would show a heterogenic mass without calcification, in contrast to the calcification seen here. Biopsy would show an acute inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils and cellular debris (liquefactive necrosis).

E) CORRECT:

Release of cytoplasmic triglycerides causes fat necrosis of the breast, which typically occurs following trauma, such as that sustained by this patient. Trauma damages adipocytes in breast tissue, spilling lipase and triglycerides into the interstitium. Triglycerides are then broken down by lipase into free fatty acids that bind with calcium to form calcium salts (saponification). The resulting inflammatory process walls off the injury as an oil cyst surrounded by necrotic, anucleate adipocytes; foam cells; and other inflammatory cells, as in the biopsy here. Fat necrosis of the breast can resemble malignancy on physical examination (painless lump) and/or imaging (calcifications), often making histological confirmation necessary.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-month history of bloody discharge from the right nipple. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 69 years. Mammography 6 months ago did not show any abnormalities. Examination of the breast shows expression of a small amount of serosanguinous fluid from the right nipple; there are no palpable breast masses or axillary lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography of the right breast shows a single dilated duct. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis in the breast classically occurs a few weeks after injury to the breast (e.g., a motor vehicle collision or a fall). It most commonly manifests as a unilateral, painless mass without associated nipple discharge. Ultrasound or mammogram characteristically shows a fluid-filled cystic structure. This patient's 3-month unilateral nipple discharge makes fat necrosis an unlikely explanation.

B) INCORRECT:

A breast lipoma is a benign, solitary, and unilateral tumor. Affected patients often report that the mass has been present for months to years, and nipple discharge would be unexpected. Examination would typically show a palpable, well-circumscribed, soft mass with distinct margins. This patient's history and signs are inconsistent with breast lipoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma may manifest with bloody nipple discharge in perimenopausal women, as seen here. However, the most common manifestation is a palpable rock-hard mass with distinct margins. Mammography of affected individuals characteristically shows clustered microcalcifications, whereas this patient had a normal mammogram. The patient's age, subacute onset of unilateral bloody nipple discharge, and reassuring mammogram are highly suggestive of another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenomas are the most common breast lesions seen in women < 35 years old, and are often associated with hyperestrogenic states (e.g., pregnancy, oral contraceptive use, or menstruation). They most commonly manifest with a smooth, mobile mass without nipple discharge. Ultrasonography classically shows a well-circumscribed, homogenous mass, but a solitary dilated duct would not be expected. This patient's age, physical examination, and serosanguinous nipple discharge are highly suggestive of another condition.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial breast tumor that most often arises in the 5th decade of life. Physical examination most commonly shows a large mass with well-defined margins deep to the breast skin without nipple discharge. On ultrasonography, characteristic hypoechoic, cystic regions are seen. Mammography often shows spiculated masses devoid of calcification. This patient's subacute onset of unilateral nipple discharge, absence of palpable breast mass, and relatively young age all make Phyllodes tumor unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the breast is most commonly seen in patients > 50 years old who are also suffering from ductal carcinoma in situ. Physical exam findings would show an erythematous and fissured areola with or without a nipple discharge. This patient's age, serosanguinous nipple discharge, and absence of cutaneous findings are not consistent with this diagnosis.
Image Description:

An erythematous, scaling rash with irregular borders and erosion of the nipple is visible on the left breast of a female patient. The pathology extends beyond the areola region.

These findings are typical of Paget's disease of the breast, a rare type of ductal carcinoma that is often accompanied by nipple discharge. Age-appropriate imaging and biopsy are required for diagnosis.

G) CORRECT:

A unilateral serosanguinous nipple discharge in a premenopausal patient with a single dilated duct is highly suggestive of an intraductal papilloma. Physical exam findings may reveal a palpable breast tumor close to the nipple. However, in most cases, intraductal papillomas are not palpable, as is the case in this patient. These lesions are typically benign but pose a slightly increased risk of cancer, thus necessitating a core needle biopsy.

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast

A well-defined solitary mass (blue overlay) is seen within a dilated mammary duct.

The main differential diagnoses are intraductal papilloma, ductal carcinoma (especially papillary carcinoma), and inspissated secretions. Secretions do not show vascularity on color Doppler. Intraductal papilloma may show a vascular stalk. Ductal carcinoma cannot always be reliably distinguished from intraductal papilloma by ultrasound.
questions.hint: The presence of a single dilated duct suggests a solitary intraductal occlusion.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening breast pain over the past 24 hours while breastfeeding her son. He was born 3 days ago via uncomplicated cesarean delivery and was feeding well but now struggles to latch to the breast. She reports tearfulness and exhaustion. She has no history of serious illness. Her grandmother passed away from breast cancer at the age of 82. The patient's current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination shows diffuse tenderness, firmness, and fullness of both breasts. The nipples appear cracked, and the areolas are erythematous and swollen bilaterally. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. There is a dry, mildly tender surgical wound above her symphysis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A breast abscess can cause breast tenderness. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of a breast abscess, such as a fluctuant mass, induration of the overlying skin, or fever. Moreover, a breast abscess most commonly develops unilaterally 2–4 weeks after delivery following an episode of mastitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Galactocele is the most common benign breast condition in lactating women. In contrast to this patient's findings, galactocele typically manifests with a firm, nontender mass in the subareolar region. Moreover, galactocele is usually not bilateral.

C) INCORRECT:

A plugged milk duct may arise in breastfeeding women when the feeding technique is not ideal (e.g., poor latching by the neonate), which is the case here. However, a plugged duct causes a localized area of milk stasis that manifests as a tender, focal, palpable mass as opposed to the diffuse tenderness and swelling seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory breast cancer can occur during pregnancy or the postpartum period and manifest with breast tenderness and swelling. However, this patient's acute onset of symptoms 2 days after delivery and the bilateral nature of symptoms make breast cancer an unlikely diagnosis. Further, inflammatory breast cancer typically manifests with features such as peau d'orange appearance of the breast, blood-tinged nipple discharge, and axillary lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

Breast engorgement typically manifests with bilateral breast tenderness, firmness, and fullness in absence of fever. Primary breast engorgement is due to increased milk production postpartum and typically occurs 3–5 days after delivery, whereas secondary engorgement is caused by insufficient demand for breast milk (e.g., due to poor latching by the neonate) typically at a later point of the postpartum period. Areola involvement can additionally interfere with breastfeeding and may worsen engorgement.

Treatment consists of frequent breastfeeding with optimal nursing techniques, warm compresses prior to breastfeeding in order to facilitate draining, cold compresses between breastfeeds to decrease milk production, and NSAIDs to reduce breast pain. A breast pump can also be used to drain the milk and reduce tension within the breast. If left untreated, prolonged breast engorgement can lead to mastitis due to milk stasis.

F) INCORRECT:

Lactational mastitis can manifest with breast tenderness, swelling, and pain during lactation. Moreover, nipple fissures facilitate entry of bacteria and increase the risk of mastitis. However, mastitis is typically unilateral and is associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., malaise, fever, and chills). In addition, mastitis usually occurs 2–4 weeks after delivery, whereas this patient's symptoms started 2 days after delivery.
questions.hint: A drop in progesterone levels after delivery causes an increase in prolactin levels. This leads to a significant increase in lactogenesis (stage II lactogenesis), which may result in a milk supply that exceeds the newborn's demand.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician 5 days after noticing a lump in her right breast. She stopped breastfeeding her 6-month-old son 1 week ago. She has not had a menstrual period since delivery. She is otherwise healthy and her only medication is a vitamin supplement. Her mother died of ovarian cancer at the age of 61 years. The patient resumed work as a fitness instructor 2 weeks ago. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, mobile, nontender mass in the right subareolar region; the overlying skin is intact. Examination of the left breast shows no abnormalities. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the right breast shows a well-demarcated, moderately heterogeneous mass with echogenic walls. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenoma, the most common benign breast tumor in women < 35 years of age, may manifest as a well-defined, solitary, mobile, nontender mass, with intact skin and no lymphadenopathy. An increase in estrogen levels (e.g., during pregnancy or hormonal therapy) may lead to enlargement of fibroadenomas. In this patient, however, estrogen levels are likely low because she is still amenorrheic and only recently stopped breastfeeding. Moreover, ultrasound would show a homogeneous mass rather than the heterogeneous mass seen here.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Galactoceles manifest as firm, nontender masses in the subareolar region that are commonly seen in women who are lactating. They frequently occur after the cessation of breastfeeding, as milk becomes stagnant and collects in the milk ducts. An ultrasound typically shows a complex mass with variable echogenicity, as the ratio of fat and water content inside the galactocele varies. Most galactoceles resolve spontaneously and patients are at no increased risk for breast cancer. Persistent symptomatic galactoceles may be managed with needle aspiration or surgical excision. A galactocele is not a contraindication to breastfeeding and mothers should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding, if possible.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast (targeted; palpable lesion) of galactoceles in two lactating women

The palpable masses in A and B are circumscribed and wider-than-tall (oriented parallel to the skin). They have thick hyperechoic walls and both hypoechoic (green overlay) and hyperechoic (yellow overlay) internal components. The palpable mass in B additionally has a hypoechoic rim (black arrows). Both lesions show posterior acoustic enhancement.

The appearances of galactoceles vary with the amounts of fluid and solid milk components contained in the lesions. They can appear cystic, mixed cystic and solid, or solid. When present, the demonstration of a fat-fluid level (dashed line) can help confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma may manifest as a palpable subareolar mass. However, intraductal papillomas are more common in women 40–50 years of age and are not associated with pregnancy or lactation. Furthermore, ultrasound typically shows a dilated duct with soft tissue echoes within the duct, and additional expected findings include bloody, serous nipple discharge, none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast may manifest as a nontender breast mass. This patient's job as a fitness instructor might have resulted in breast trauma, a common cause of fat necrosis of the breast. However, a well-demarcated, moderately heterogeneous mass with echogenic walls on ultrasound is not consistent with fat necrosis of the breast, which is more likely to manifest as a fluid-filled oil cyst with coarse rim calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammary duct ectasia may manifest with a firm subareolar mass. However, mammary duct ectasia is more commonly seen in perimenopausal women and is, therefore, unlikely in this 34-year-old patient. Moreover, additional expected findings in mammary duct ectasia include unilateral creamy discharge, nipple inversion, pain, and dilated ducts on ultrasound, none of which are present in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient likely has a benign breast lesion commonly seen in women who are lactating.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent episodes of diffuse, bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The episodes occur every 4–5 weeks. Medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She plays on the local basketball team and practices 3–4 times weekly. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tender, soft, symmetric breasts without palpable masses, skin changes, or nipple discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide reassurance and prescribe oral ibuprofen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rest and heat application can be effective for the treatment of extramammary musculoskeletal chest pain. This patient plays sports regularly, which can cause musculoskeletal injuries. However, extramammary chest pain does not typically follow a cyclical pattern and usually does not affect both sides equally. This patient's presentation is consistent with cyclical mastalgia, for which heat application can be helpful but rest or activity restriction is not required.

B) CORRECT:

Cyclical mastalgia is typically caused by hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle. The initial step in the management of cyclical mastalgia is to provide reassurance (to reduce patient anxiety about a potential malignancy), provide topical or oral analgesics (e.g., diclofenac gel, oral ibuprofen or acetaminophen), and recommend supportive measures such as cold or warm compresses and support garments (e.g., well-fitting, soft bras). For patients who are on oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy, discontinuing or reducing the dose of these medications can be trialed. Breast imaging (ultrasound or mammography) is not routinely indicated in cyclical mastalgia. In patients with severe cyclical mastalgia that persists after 6 months of first-line therapy, tamoxifen should be considered as a second-line treatment.

See “Overview of mastalgia” table.

C) INCORRECT:

For a patient with mastalgia, breast imaging (ultrasound or mammography) is indicated if there are features that raise suspicion for malignancy (e.g., focal noncyclical mastalgia, breast mass, skin changes, nipple discharge). This patient has a normal clinical breast examination and cyclical mastalgia, for which breast imaging is not routinely indicated. Furthermore, for a patient < 30 years of age, ultrasound, rather than mammography, is the preferred modality for breast imaging as the higher breast tissue density makes detection of breast abnormalities with mammography more difficult.

Mammography is also indicated for routine breast cancer screening but in the absence of significant risk factors for breast cancer (e.g., positive family history), screening starts at 40 years of age, at the earliest.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral tamoxifen is the preferred second-line therapy for cyclical mastalgia and should be considered if breast pain persists after 6 months of first-line treatment. This patient has not received any treatment yet, making a different step more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the dose of or discontinuing, rather than starting, combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) can be trialed in patients with cyclical mastalgia. Some patients experience symptom relief after reducing the dose of estrogen.
questions.hint: Diffuse, bilateral breast pain that occurs at regular intervals is consistent with cyclical mastalgia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation because of a 2-day history of a painful lump in the left breast, fever, and malaise. Yesterday, she noticed a discoloration of the skin at the site of the lump. One month ago, she gave birth to a healthy boy who she had been exclusively breastfeeding until 1 week ago when she was diagnosed with lactational mastitis. She has stopped breastfeeding since then because “it was too painful.” She has no history of serious illness. She smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped when she became pregnant. Current medications include cephalexin and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows erythema and warmth of the lateral left breast and a 6-cm fluctuant, tender mass. The skin overlying the mass is thin and purplish. There are fissures on both nipples. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Manual massage and warm compress application

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin is typically used to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. This patient, however, developed a breast abscess as a complication of her lactational mastitis, which is most likely due to an infection with Staphylococcus aureus, a gram-positive bacterium, against which gentamicin is not effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual massage and warm compress application can be used by patients with milk duct obstruction, which can develop after abrupt cessation of breastfeeding. While an obstructed milk duct can manifest with a tender breast mass, it would not explain this patient's local erythema, skin necrosis, or systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, tachycardia). Manual massage and warm compress application have no role in the treatment of a breast abscess.

C) CORRECT:

Surgical incision and drainage is the treatment of choice for breast abscesses that are complicated by overlying skin necrosis or those that fail to respond to less invasive treatment attempts. Thereafter, patients are treated with empiric antibiotics for breast infections while an abscess culture is pending. Risk factors for breast abscess formation as a complication of puerperal mastitis include breastfeeding, advanced age (> 30 years), primiparity, and positive smoking history.

Small, uncomplicated breast abscesses with intact skin are treated with antibiotics and fine-needle aspiration.

D) INCORRECT:

Continued breastfeeding and symptomatic treatment (e.g., cold compresses, analgesics) is the first step in the management of uncomplicated lactational mastitis. Because this patient developed a breast abscess as a complication of lactational mastitis, a different intervention is required at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration is the recommended treatment for breast abscesses with intact overlying skin. This patient, however, developed skin necrosis, which requires a different intervention.
questions.hint: This patient's erythematous, fluctuant breast mass associated with fever, chills, and local skin involvement is consistent with a breast abscess complicated by skin necrosis.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a follow-up examination 6 weeks after presenting with a painless mass in her left breast. Breast and pubic hair development began at the age of 10 years. Menarche started at the age of 13 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 5 days ago. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears well and is at the 65th percentile for both height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 3. Palpation of the left breast shows a nontender, rubbery, discrete, and mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant. There are no overlying skin changes or associated warmth and no nipple retraction or discharge; these findings are unchanged since the last visit. Examination of the right breast and axillary lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the left breast shows a well-circumscribed, solid 1.5 x 1.1-cm mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up examination in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most common palpable breast mass in patients < 35 years of age is fibroadenoma, a benign breast tumor that has a good prognosis and often resolves spontaneously. A biopsy would confirm the diagnosis but can be avoided in adolescent patients who have ultrasound findings consistent with fibroadenoma (i.e., a solid mass with well-defined borders) and low clinical suspicion of malignancy (e.g., no systemic symptoms, no red flags for breast cancer, such as nipple discharge and skin retraction). Adolescent patients with a breast mass consistent with fibroadenoma are typically managed with follow-up examinations every 6–12 months for 1–2 years. Follow-up is necessary to evaluate for tumor growth, which would warrant further investigation and potentially surgical excision to exclude rare differential diagnoses (e.g., phyllodes tumor, malignancy).
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the evaluation of palpable breast masses in individuals ≥ 40 years of age. This modality is also recommended for breast cancer screening because it can detect the majority of malignancies and lesions ∼ 2 years before they are clinically evident as palpable masses. However, mammography is less sensitive in younger patients who have greater breast density due to high amounts of glandular tissue and is typically not used in individuals < 30 years of age. Finally, this patient's ultrasound and examination findings are consistent with fibroadenoma, for which further imaging is likely not necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) can be used to evaluate cystic breast lesions. If clear nonbloody fluid is aspirated and the lesion resolves, a simple cyst is the most likely diagnosis. Other fluids (e.g., bloody discharge) require further cytological evaluation. This patient's ultrasound findings show a solid mass, for which FNA is not the best diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient most likely has a fibroadenoma, a benign tumor that often resolves spontaneously, reassurance alone is not sufficient. Follow-up is necessary to evaluate for tumor growth, which would warrant further investigation to exclude rare differential diagnoses (e.g., phyllodes tumor, malignancy).

E) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy is only indicated in adolescent patients with a palpable breast mass that is > 5 cm in diameter and/or growing larger. Excision may also be indicated for suspected breast lesions (firm, nontender masses, with poorly-defined margins) and/or for masses that cause excessive worry for the patient or caregivers. This patient likely has a small fibroadenoma (< 2 cm in diameter), which requires a different step in management.
questions.hint: In an otherwise healthy adolescent, a nontender breast mass that remains unchanged for 6 weeks and is solid with well-defined borders on ultrasound suggests fibroadenoma.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 41 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: clinic
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: routine breast cancer screening
History of Present Illness:

occasional mild breast tenderness that self-resolves
menarche at 12 years of age, regular menstrual cycles
last menstrual period began 3 days ago

gravida 1, para 0, pregnancy was 2 years ago
no history of breast, uterine, ovarian, or colorectal cancers

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
oral contraceptive pill
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
no family history of breast cancer
Psychosocial History:

smokes one pack of cigarettes per week
does not drink alcohol or use any other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp

O2 Sat

Wt

37.2°C(99.0°F)
82/min
16/min
120/70 mm Hg
