25 kg/m2




Appearance: appears well; no acute distress
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx
Neck: no cervical lymphadenopathy
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Chest: normal, symmetrical breasts with no masses on palpation; no nipple discharge or overlying skin changes; no axillary lymphadenopathy
Pelvic: mild vulvovaginal atrophy; no cervical tenderness; uterus normal in size and shape; no adnexal masses or tenderness 

Diagnostic Studies
mammography: extremely dense breast tissue throughout; one group of clustered, amorphous microcalcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma mainly affects individuals between 30 and 50 years of age and mammography findings may include calcifications, but the condition typically manifests with a palpable, retroareolar mass that is well-defined and has regular borders on imaging.

B) CORRECT:

Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is often detected early on mammography screening as grouped, amorphous microcalcifications. In contrast, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) does not typically manifest with calcifications and is difficult to detect on standard breast imaging. Although DCIS and LCIS are technically considered nonmalignant because they do not cross the basement membrane, both increase the risk of invasive breast cancer. Mammography findings that raise suspicion for malignancy include grouped microcalcifications, an irregularly shaped mass with indistinct borders and spiculated margins, and a high breast density. See “Features of breast mass on mammography” table.
Image Description:

Mammography (right breast; mediolateral oblique view)

A high-density mass (green overlay) with an indistinct margin and containing microcalcifications (examples indicated by red overlay) projects in the upper breast.

The features of this lesion are highly suspicious for malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Sclerosing adenosis is a common benign lesion of the breast and may manifest with cyclic mastalgia and calcifications on mammography, but the calcifications are typically diffuse rather than clustered.

D) INCORRECT:

Mondor disease of the breast may manifest with noncyclical mastalgia, but the typical manifestation is the sudden onset of a tender, cord-like induration, which corresponds to a superficial tubular structure that has a beaded appearance on mammography.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast can resemble malignancy and manifest with grouped calcifications on mammography. However, the calcifications typically have a coarse rim or eggshell appearance, and the findings are frequently associated with a spiculated mass or fluid-filled oil cyst. Moreover, fat necrosis often involves skin changes (e.g., reaction, erythema, and ecchymosis) and a history of trauma, surgery, or radiation of the breast.
questions.hint: Risk factors associated with this condition include nulliparity, obesity, early menarche, and late menopause.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent aching pain in her left breast. She reports that the pain occurs 1–2 times every week, lasts a few hours, and is not associated with any specific activity but it interferes with her ability to concentrate at work or to fall asleep. She has not had any nipple discharge. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with normal flow; her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She drinks 2–4 glasses of wine on weekends; she does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Her maternal grandmother developed aortic valve stenosis in her mid-70s; her family history is otherwise noncontributary. The patient is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the breast shows no visible skin changes or nipple abnormalities. There is mild tenderness in the lower outer quadrant of the left breast but no masses are felt on palpation. There is no lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination, including cardiopulmonary examination, shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Noncyclical mastalgia most commonly affects women 30–50 years of age and is often related to internal breast changes, previous surgeries, injuries, infections, or other breast pathologies (e.g., fibroadenomas, cysts). All patients with noncyclical mastalgia should receive diagnostic imaging to screen for breast cancer because of the rare association with malignancy. Ultrasonography is typically used to screen for breast cancer in patients < 30 years of age because women in this age group typically have increased breast tissue density. Ultrasound increases the sensitivity of mammography if used in tandem. After malignancy is ruled out, conservative therapy may be employed and includes hot and cold compresses, topical/oral analgesics as necessary, dietary modifications (e.g., reducing caffeine and high-fat foods), and the use of a well-fitting bra. (See “Overview of mastalgia” table).

Tamoxifen may be prescribed to patients whose symptoms do not resolve within 6 months of conservative treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

While cyclical mastalgia is a consequence of the hormonal fluctuations associated with menstrual cycles, the use of oral contraceptive therapy (OCP) is not used to treat breast pain associated with cyclical mastalgia. OCPs are considered a cause of mastalgia, rather than a treatment. Finally, this patient's symptoms are not associated with her menstrual cycle.

C) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, noncyclical mastalgia occurs in the setting of malignancy. Therefore, all patients with noncyclical mastalgia should be screened for breast cancer. While mammography is the gold standard for breast cancer screening in patients > 30 years of age, another imaging modality is preferred in patients < 30 years because breast tissue density is typically increased in this population.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and conservative management, such as hot and cold compresses, topical/oral analgesics (e.g., diclofenac) as necessary, dietary modifications (e.g., reducing caffeine and high-fat foods), and the use of a well-fitting bra, is appropriate in patients with cyclical mastalgia, diffuse noncyclical mastalgia, or extramammary mastalgia due to a musculoskeletal etiology. However, reassurance and conservative therapy in a patient with focal noncyclical mastalgia would not be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., duloxetine) can be used in the management of fibromyalgia which typically manifests in female patients between 20–50 years of age who present with symptoms of focal pain and difficulty concentrating. However, fibromyalgia typically manifests with at least 7 of the 19 identified widespread pain index tenderpoints.
questions.hint: This patient presents with focal noncyclical mastalgia.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a lump that she noticed incidentally on her right breast 4 weeks ago while taking a shower. She initially thought the lump would disappear, but it has persisted without any change in size. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago; it typically occurs every 28 days and lasts for 4 days. She is not sexually active and does not take oral contraceptives. Her mother had metastatic breast cancer diagnosed at 62 years of age.
Physical examination reveals a firm, mobile, painless mass at the right outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no notable skin changes or palpable lymph nodes.
Breast ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic, solid lesion with well-circumscribed borders.
Which one of the following findings would be most likely on a breast biopsy of the mass?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lipomas can manifest similarly to fibroadenomas — as painless, palpable, mobile breast masses. However, they are usually described as soft or doughy on palpation, whereas fibroadenomas are firmer. In addition, on ultrasound, lipomas appear as isoechoic or hyperechoic compared with surrounding tissues.

B) INCORRECT:

Breast carcinoma has many possible manifestations, including as a solid mass, and there may be associated skin changes (peau d’orange), nipple discharge, or axillary lymphadenopathy. On ultrasound, breast carcinoma may appear hypoechoic (similar to fibroadenoma), but it will often have an irregular shape and indistinct margins. In this case, breast carcinoma is a possible diagnosis, but it is much less likely than a fibroadenoma, given the patient’s age, the lack of associated concerning features, and the ultrasound findings.

C) INCORRECT:

A fibrocystic mass (an umbrella term used for several types of nonmalignant lesions) is not the most likely diagnosis in this case, as fibrocystic breast changes are typically associated with breast pain, with multiple lumps (described as nodular), and with size changes during the menstrual cycle

D) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast also manifests as a palpable mass, but it is usually located in the subareolar or periareolar areas and is associated with breast trauma, fine-needle aspiration, radiation, or breast infection. On examination, there can be skin tethering and nipple retraction related to adhesions between necrotic tissue and skin. Fat necrosis is also more common in older women. It is therefore unlikely in this case.

E) CORRECT:

Women who present with a breast mass should undergo further evaluation to rule out breast cancer, even if they are young. Mammography is typically the first step in evaluation for women older than 30 to 35 years, but it is not as appropriate in younger women, who tend to have denser breasts. Breast ultrasound is the preferred first step for a young woman with a breast mass. This patient’s ultrasound findings and clinical presentation are most consistent with a fibroadenoma.

Fibroadenomas are painless, unilateral, benign tumors that develop within the upper outer quadrant of the breast and manifest as solid masses. They can occur at any age but are typically found in younger women (aged 20 to 30 years). The cause of fibroadenomas is unclear, but there may be a hormonal component given that they are more common in younger women and in women who take oral contraceptives.

On ultrasound, fibroadenomas appear as circumscribed, round, lobulated masses with uniform echogenicity. To further evaluate whether the mass is benign or malignant, a breast biopsy should be pursued, particularly in a patient with a first-degree relative who has had breast cancer.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis on biopsy of a palpable breast mass in a woman <35 years of age is a fibroadenoma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of a painful lump in the left breast, fever, and malaise. Yesterday, she noticed a discoloration of the skin at the site of the lump. One month ago, she gave birth to a healthy boy who she had been exclusively breastfeeding until 1 week ago when she was diagnosed with lactational mastitis. She has stopped breastfeeding since then because “it was too painful.” Current medications include cephalexin and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Examination shows erythema and warmth of the lateral left breast and a 6-cm fluctuant, tender mass. The skin overlying the mass is thin and purplish. There are fissures on both nipples. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Manual massage and warm compress application

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin is typically used to treat gram-negative bacterial infections. This patient, however, developed a breast abscess as a complication of her lactational mastitis, which is most likely due to an infection with Staphylococcus aureus, a gram-positive bacterium, against which gentamicin is not effective.

B) INCORRECT:

Manual massage and warm compress application can be used by patients with milk duct obstruction, which can develop after abrupt cessation of breastfeeding. While an obstructed milk duct can manifest with a tender breast mass, it would not explain this patient's local erythema, skin necrosis, or systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, tachycardia). Manual massage and warm compress application have no role in the treatment of a breast abscess.

C) CORRECT:

Surgical incision and drainage is the treatment of choice for breast abscesses that are complicated by overlying skin necrosis or those that fail to respond to less invasive treatment attempts. Thereafter, patients are treated with empiric antibiotics for breast infections while an abscess culture is pending. Risk factors for breast abscess formation as a complication of puerperal mastitis include breastfeeding, advanced age (> 30 years), primiparity, and positive smoking history.

Small, uncomplicated breast abscesses with intact skin are treated with antibiotics and fine-needle aspiration.

D) INCORRECT:

Continued breastfeeding and symptomatic treatment (e.g., cold compresses, analgesics) is the first step in the management of uncomplicated lactational mastitis. Because this patient developed a breast abscess as a complication of lactational mastitis, a different intervention is required at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration is the recommended treatment for breast abscesses with intact overlying skin. This patient, however, developed skin necrosis, which requires a different intervention.
questions.hint: This patient's erythematous, fluctuant breast mass associated with fever, chills, and local skin involvement is consistent with a breast abscess complicated by skin necrosis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a mass in the left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. During this period, the mass has not increased in size and the patient has had no pain. Three months ago, she hit her left chest against the closet door and it was painful for a day. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Physical examination shows dense breasts and a 2.5-cm well-defined, rubbery, nontender mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumors may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. This 29-year-old woman lacks the characteristic symptoms of phyllodes tumor, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes of the breast are the most common benign lesions of the breast and typically manifest with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On exam, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

A nontender, well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency in a 29-year-old woman with no mastalgia, no changes in the skin over the breast, nor axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Fibroadenomas should be closely monitored with clinical breast examinations and imaging (ultrasound and/or mammogram). Ultrasound-guided biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy if lesions increase in size or have atypical imaging findings (e.g., calcifications).

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma is usually associated with suspicious characteristics, including: age > 35 years, positive family history, skin changes, axillary adenopathy, asymmetry, and a firm, rigid mass with irregular borders. None of these features are present in this patient, meaning that carcinoma is unlikely. Nevertheless, this patient should undergo mammography to rule out any potential suspicious radiological signs.

E) INCORRECT:

Although patients with fat necrosis of the breast commonly report a history of breast trauma, this condition typically manifests as a firm, periareolar mass with irregular borders that may have an overlying area of skin thickening or retraction. This patient's well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency makes a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast is likely to show a well-defined mass with homogeneous hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for a follow-up examination 6 weeks after presenting with a painless mass in her left breast. Menarche started at the age of 13 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 5 days ago. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 3. Palpation of the left breast shows a nontender, rubbery, discrete, and mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant. There are no overlying skin changes or associated warmth and no nipple retraction or discharge; these findings are unchanged since the last visit. Examination of the right breast and axillary lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the left breast shows a well-circumscribed, solid 1.5 x 1.1-cm mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and follow-up examination in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most common palpable breast mass in patients < 35 years of age is fibroadenoma, a benign breast tumor that has a good prognosis and often resolves spontaneously. A biopsy would confirm the diagnosis but can be avoided in adolescent patients who have ultrasound findings consistent with fibroadenoma (i.e., a solid mass with well-defined borders) and low clinical suspicion of malignancy (e.g., no systemic symptoms, no red flags for breast cancer, such as nipple discharge and skin retraction). Adolescent patients with a breast mass consistent with fibroadenoma are typically managed with follow-up examinations every 6–12 months for 1–2 years. Follow-up is necessary to evaluate for tumor growth, which would warrant further investigation and potentially surgical excision to exclude rare differential diagnoses (e.g., phyllodes tumor, malignancy).
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mammography is used for the evaluation of palpable breast masses in individuals ≥ 40 years of age. This modality is also recommended for breast cancer screening because it can detect the majority of malignancies and lesions ∼ 2 years before they are clinically evident as palpable masses. However, mammography is less sensitive in younger patients who have greater breast density due to high amounts of glandular tissue and is typically not used in individuals < 30 years of age. Finally, this patient's ultrasound and examination findings are consistent with fibroadenoma, for which further imaging is likely not necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) can be used to evaluate cystic breast lesions. If clear nonbloody fluid is aspirated and the lesion resolves, a simple cyst is the most likely diagnosis. Other fluids (e.g., bloody discharge) require further cytological evaluation. This patient's ultrasound findings show a solid mass, for which FNA is not the best diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient most likely has a fibroadenoma, a benign tumor that often resolves spontaneously, reassurance alone is not sufficient. Follow-up is necessary to evaluate for tumor growth, which would warrant further investigation to exclude rare differential diagnoses (e.g., phyllodes tumor, malignancy).

E) INCORRECT:

Excisional biopsy is only indicated in adolescent patients with a palpable breast mass that is > 5 cm in diameter and/or growing larger. Excision may also be indicated for suspected breast lesions (firm, nontender masses, with poorly-defined margins) and/or for masses that cause excessive worry for the patient or caregivers. This patient likely has a small fibroadenoma (< 2 cm in diameter), which requires a different step in management.
questions.hint: In an otherwise healthy adolescent, a nontender breast mass that remains unchanged for 6 weeks and is solid with well-defined borders on ultrasound suggests fibroadenoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman reports progressively worsening breast pain over the past 24 hours while breastfeeding her son. He was born 3 days ago via uncomplicated cesarean delivery and was feeding well but now struggles to latch to the breast. The patient's current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination shows diffuse tenderness, firmness, and fullness of both breasts. The nipples appear cracked, and the areolas are erythematous and swollen bilaterally. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A breast abscess can cause breast tenderness. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of a breast abscess, such as a fluctuant mass, induration of the overlying skin, or fever. Moreover, a breast abscess most commonly develops unilaterally 2–4 weeks after delivery following an episode of mastitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Galactocele is the most common benign breast condition in lactating women. In contrast to this patient's findings, galactocele typically manifests with a firm, nontender mass in the subareolar region. Moreover, galactocele is usually not bilateral.

C) INCORRECT:

A plugged milk duct may arise in breastfeeding women when the feeding technique is not ideal (e.g., poor latching by the neonate), which is the case here. However, a plugged duct causes a localized area of milk stasis that manifests as a tender, focal, palpable mass as opposed to the diffuse tenderness and swelling seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Breast engorgement typically manifests with bilateral breast tenderness, firmness, and fullness in absence of fever. Primary breast engorgement is due to increased milk production postpartum and typically occurs 3–5 days after delivery, whereas secondary engorgement is caused by insufficient demand for breast milk (e.g., due to poor latching by the neonate) typically at a later point of the postpartum period. Areola involvement can additionally interfere with breastfeeding and may worsen engorgement.

Treatment consists of frequent breastfeeding with optimal nursing techniques, warm compresses prior to breastfeeding in order to facilitate draining, cold compresses between breastfeeds to decrease milk production, and NSAIDs to reduce breast pain. A breast pump can also be used to drain the milk and reduce tension within the breast. If left untreated, prolonged breast engorgement can lead to mastitis due to milk stasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactational mastitis can manifest with breast tenderness, swelling, and pain during lactation. Moreover, nipple fissures facilitate entry of bacteria and increase the risk of mastitis. However, mastitis is typically unilateral and is associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., malaise, fever, and chills). In addition, mastitis usually occurs 2–4 weeks after delivery, whereas this patient's symptoms started 2 days after delivery.
questions.hint: A drop in progesterone levels after delivery causes an increase in prolactin levels. This leads to a significant increase in lactogenesis (stage II lactogenesis), which may result in a milk supply that exceeds the newborn's demand.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office because of intermittent episodes of diffuse, bilateral breast pain for the past 4 months. The episodes occur every 4–5 weeks. Medical history is unremarkable and she takes no medications. Menses occur at regular intervals. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She plays on the local basketball team and practices 3–4 times weekly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tender, soft, symmetric breasts without palpable masses, skin changes, or nipple discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide reassurance and prescribe oral ibuprofen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rest and heat application can be effective for the treatment of extramammary musculoskeletal chest pain. This patient plays sports regularly, which can cause musculoskeletal injuries. However, extramammary chest pain does not typically follow a cyclical pattern and usually does not affect both sides equally. This patient's presentation is consistent with cyclical mastalgia, for which heat application can be helpful but rest or activity restriction is not required.

B) CORRECT:

Cyclical mastalgia is typically caused by hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle. The initial step in the management of cyclical mastalgia is to provide reassurance (to reduce patient anxiety about a potential malignancy), provide topical or oral analgesics (e.g., diclofenac gel, oral ibuprofen or acetaminophen), and recommend supportive measures such as cold or warm compresses and support garments (e.g., well-fitting, soft bras). For patients who are on oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy, discontinuing or reducing the dose of these medications can be trialed. Breast imaging (ultrasound or mammography) is not routinely indicated in cyclical mastalgia. In patients with severe cyclical mastalgia that persists after 6 months of first-line therapy, tamoxifen should be considered as a second-line treatment.

See “Overview of mastalgia” table.

C) INCORRECT:

For a patient with mastalgia, breast imaging (ultrasound or mammography) is indicated if there are features that raise suspicion for malignancy (e.g., focal noncyclical mastalgia, breast mass, skin changes, nipple discharge). This patient has a normal clinical breast examination and cyclical mastalgia, for which breast imaging is not routinely indicated. Furthermore, for a patient < 30 years of age, ultrasound, rather than mammography, is the preferred modality for breast imaging as the higher breast tissue density makes detection of breast abnormalities with mammography more difficult.

Mammography is also indicated for routine breast cancer screening but in the absence of significant risk factors for breast cancer (e.g., positive family history), screening starts at 40 years of age, at the earliest.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral tamoxifen is the preferred second-line therapy for cyclical mastalgia and should be considered if breast pain persists after 6 months of first-line treatment. This patient has not received any treatment yet, making a different step more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the dose of or discontinuing, rather than starting, combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) can be trialed in patients with cyclical mastalgia. Some patients experience symptom relief after reducing the dose of estrogen.
questions.hint: Diffuse, bilateral breast pain that occurs at regular intervals is consistent with cyclical mastalgia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the office 5 days after noticing a lump in her right breast. She stopped breastfeeding her 6-month-old son 1 week ago. She has not had a menstrual period since delivery. The patient resumed work as a fitness instructor 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 3-cm, mobile, nontender mass in the right subareolar region; the overlying skin is intact. Examination of the left breast shows no abnormalities. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography of the right breast shows a well-demarcated, moderately heterogeneous mass with echogenic walls. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenoma, the most common benign breast tumor in women < 35 years of age, may manifest as a well-defined, solitary, mobile, nontender mass, with intact skin and no lymphadenopathy. An increase in estrogen levels (e.g., during pregnancy or hormonal therapy) may lead to enlargement of fibroadenomas. In this patient, however, estrogen levels are likely low because she is still amenorrheic and only recently stopped breastfeeding. Moreover, ultrasound would show a homogeneous mass rather than the heterogeneous mass seen here.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast of a fibroadenoma

A partially heterogeneous (blue overlay), hypoechoic, oval macrolobulated lesion with circumscribed margins has a thin echogenic rim (pseudocapsule, indicated by white line). The lesion is wider than tall (parallel orientation) and shows subtle posterior acoustic enhancement (yellow overlay).

Fibroadenomas are typically oval and homogeneous, wider than tall, and isoechoic to hypoechoic compared to adjacent fat. Coarse calcifications may be present. Biopsy can be performed if the clinical history and/or mass features indicate the need for tissue diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Galactoceles manifest as firm, nontender masses in the subareolar region that are commonly seen in women who are lactating. They frequently occur after the cessation of breastfeeding, as milk becomes stagnant and collects in the milk ducts. An ultrasound typically shows a complex mass with variable echogenicity, as the ratio of fat and water content inside the galactocele varies. Most galactoceles resolve spontaneously and patients are at no increased risk for breast cancer. Persistent symptomatic galactoceles may be managed with needle aspiration or surgical excision. A galactocele is not a contraindication to breastfeeding and mothers should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding, if possible.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast (targeted; palpable lesion) of galactoceles in two lactating women

The palpable masses in A and B are circumscribed and wider-than-tall (oriented parallel to the skin). They have thick hyperechoic walls and both hypoechoic (green overlay) and hyperechoic (yellow overlay) internal components. The palpable mass in B additionally has a hypoechoic rim (black arrows). Both lesions show posterior acoustic enhancement.

The appearances of galactoceles vary with the amounts of fluid and solid milk components contained in the lesions. They can appear cystic, mixed cystic and solid, or solid. When present, the demonstration of a fat-fluid level (dashed line) can help confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma may manifest as a palpable subareolar mass. However, intraductal papillomas are more common in women 40–50 years of age and are not associated with pregnancy or lactation. Furthermore, ultrasound typically shows a dilated duct with soft tissue echoes within the duct, and additional expected findings include bloody, serous nipple discharge, none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast may manifest as a nontender breast mass. This patient's job as a fitness instructor might have resulted in breast trauma, a common cause of fat necrosis of the breast. However, a well-demarcated, moderately heterogeneous mass with echogenic walls on ultrasound is not consistent with fat necrosis of the breast, which is more likely to manifest as a fluid-filled oil cyst with coarse rim calcifications.

E) INCORRECT:

Mammary duct ectasia may manifest with a firm subareolar mass. However, mammary duct ectasia is more commonly seen in perimenopausal women and is, therefore, unlikely in this 34-year-old patient. Moreover, additional expected findings in mammary duct ectasia include unilateral creamy discharge, nipple inversion, pain, and dilated ducts on ultrasound, none of which are present in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient likely has a benign breast lesion commonly seen in women who are lactating.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to your clinic for evaluation of a mass in her left breast that she first noticed 2 weeks ago. The mass has not changed in size and she has not experienced any pain. She recalls hitting her left chest against a closet door 3 months ago, which caused pain for one day. Her menstrual cycles are regular every 28 days, lasting 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. On examination, her breasts are dense and there is a 2.5-cm, well-defined, rubbery, nontender, mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no axillary adenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although patients with fat necrosis of the breast commonly report a history of breast trauma, this condition typically manifests as a firm, periareolar mass with irregular borders that may have an overlying area of skin thickening or retraction. This patient's well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) CORRECT:

A nontender, well-defined mobile mass with a rubbery consistency in a 29-year-old woman with no mastalgia, no changes in the skin over the breast, nor axillary lymphadenopathy indicates fibroadenoma. Fibroadenoma is the most common breast tumor in women < 35 years of age. Fibroadenomas should be closely monitored with clinical breast examinations and imaging (ultrasound and/or mammogram). Ultrasound-guided biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy if lesions increase in size or have atypical imaging findings (e.g., calcifications).

See “Overview of benign neoplasms of the breast” table.

Key learning point: A well-circumscribed, mobile, rubbery, nontender breast mass in a woman under 35 is most likely a fibroadenoma, the most common benign breast tumor in young women.

C) INCORRECT:

Phyllodes tumors are generally large (average diameter of 4–7 cm), and typically affect patients between 40–50 years of age. Also, patients with phyllodes tumors may notice an increase in the size of a breast mass a few weeks after discovering it. This 29-year-old woman lacks the characteristic symptoms of phyllodes tumor, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrocystic changes of the breast are the most common benign lesions of the breast and typically manifest with premenstrual breast pain that may be recurring or constant and unilateral or bilateral. On exam, areas of suspected growth tend to be diffuse as opposed to the focal, circumscribed mass found in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Lobular carcinoma is usually associated with suspicious characteristics, including: age > 35 years, positive family history, skin changes, axillary adenopathy, asymmetry, and a firm, rigid mass with irregular borders. None of these features are present in this patient, meaning that carcinoma is unlikely. Nevertheless, this patient should undergo mammography to rule out any potential suspicious radiological signs.
questions.hint: An ultrasound of the breast is likely to show a well-defined mass with homogeneous hypoechogenicity.

questions.text: You are seeing a 30-year-old woman who reports progressively worsening breast pain over the past 24 hours while breastfeeding her son. Her son was born 3 days ago by uncomplicated cesarean delivery and had been feeding well, but now has difficulty latching. She is currently taking folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C. On examination, there is diffuse tenderness, firmness, and fullness of both breasts. The nipples are cracked, and the areolas are erythematous and swollen bilaterally. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lactational mastitis can manifest with breast tenderness, swelling, and pain during lactation. Moreover, nipple fissures facilitate entry of bacteria and increase the risk of mastitis. However, mastitis is typically unilateral and is associated with systemic symptoms (e.g., malaise, fever, and chills). In addition, mastitis usually occurs 2–4 weeks after delivery, whereas this patient's symptoms started 2 days after delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

A breast abscess can cause breast tenderness. However, this patient lacks other characteristic features of a breast abscess, such as a fluctuant mass, induration of the overlying skin, or fever. Moreover, a breast abscess most commonly develops unilaterally 2–4 weeks after delivery following an episode of mastitis.

C) CORRECT:

Breast engorgement typically manifests with bilateral breast tenderness, firmness, and fullness in absence of fever. Primary breast engorgement is due to increased milk production postpartum and typically occurs 3–5 days after delivery, whereas secondary engorgement is caused by insufficient demand for breast milk (e.g., due to poor latching by the neonate) typically at a later point of the postpartum period. Areola involvement can additionally interfere with breastfeeding and may worsen engorgement.

Treatment consists of frequent breastfeeding with optimal nursing techniques, warm compresses prior to breastfeeding in order to facilitate draining, cold compresses between breastfeeds to decrease milk production, and NSAIDs to reduce breast pain. A breast pump can also be used to drain the milk and reduce tension within the breast. If left untreated, prolonged breast engorgement can lead to mastitis due to milk stasis.

Key learning point: Breast engorgement typically presents 3–5 days postpartum with bilateral breast tenderness, firmness, and fullness without fever, often due to increased milk production or insufficient milk removal.

D) INCORRECT:

A plugged milk duct may arise in breastfeeding women when the feeding technique is not ideal (e.g., poor latching by the neonate), which is the case here. However, a plugged duct causes a localized area of milk stasis that manifests as a tender, focal, palpable mass as opposed to the diffuse tenderness and swelling seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Galactocele is the most common benign breast condition in lactating women. In contrast to this patient's findings, galactocele typically manifests with a firm, nontender mass in the subareolar region. Moreover, galactocele is usually not bilateral.
questions.hint: A drop in progesterone levels after delivery causes an increase in prolactin levels. This leads to a significant increase in lactogenesis (stage II lactogenesis), which may result in a milk supply that exceeds the newborn's demand.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to your clinic 5 days after noticing a lump in her right breast. She stopped breastfeeding her 6-month-old son 1 week ago. She has not had a menstrual period since delivery. She recently resumed work as a fitness instructor 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a 3-cm, mobile, nontender mass in the right subareolar region with intact overlying skin. The left breast is normal. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Ultrasonography of the right breast shows a well-demarcated, moderately heterogeneous mass with echogenic walls. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Galactoceles manifest as firm, nontender masses in the subareolar region that are commonly seen in women who are lactating. They frequently occur after the cessation of breastfeeding, as milk becomes stagnant and collects in the milk ducts. An ultrasound typically shows a complex mass with variable echogenicity, as the ratio of fat and water content inside the galactocele varies. Most galactoceles resolve spontaneously and patients are at no increased risk for breast cancer. Persistent symptomatic galactoceles may be managed with needle aspiration or surgical excision. A galactocele is not a contraindication to breastfeeding and mothers should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding, if possible.

Key learning point: A galactocele is a benign, nontender breast mass that typically develops after cessation of breastfeeding due to milk retention and usually resolves spontaneously.
Image Description:

Ultrasound breast (targeted; palpable lesion) of galactoceles in two lactating women

The palpable masses in A and B are circumscribed and wider-than-tall (oriented parallel to the skin). They have thick hyperechoic walls and both hypoechoic (green overlay) and hyperechoic (yellow overlay) internal components. The palpable mass in B additionally has a hypoechoic rim (black arrows). Both lesions show posterior acoustic enhancement.

The appearances of galactoceles vary with the amounts of fluid and solid milk components contained in the lesions. They can appear cystic, mixed cystic and solid, or solid. When present, the demonstration of a fat-fluid level (dashed line) can help confirm the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraductal papilloma may manifest as a palpable subareolar mass. However, intraductal papillomas are more common in women 40–50 years of age and are not associated with pregnancy or lactation. Furthermore, ultrasound typically shows a dilated duct with soft tissue echoes within the duct, and additional expected findings include bloody, serous nipple discharge, none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Fibroadenoma, the most common benign breast tumor in women < 35 years of age, may manifest as a well-defined, solitary, mobile, nontender mass, with intact skin and no lymphadenopathy. An increase in estrogen levels (e.g., during pregnancy or hormonal therapy) may lead to enlargement of fibroadenomas. In this patient, however, estrogen levels are likely low because she is still amenorrheic and only recently stopped breastfeeding. Moreover, ultrasound would show a homogeneous mass rather than the heterogeneous mass seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Mammary duct ectasia may manifest with a firm subareolar mass. However, mammary duct ectasia is more commonly seen in perimenopausal women and is, therefore, unlikely in this 34-year-old patient. Moreover, additional expected findings in mammary duct ectasia include unilateral creamy discharge, nipple inversion, pain, and dilated ducts on ultrasound, none of which are present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast may manifest as a nontender breast mass. This patient's job as a fitness instructor might have resulted in breast trauma, a common cause of fat necrosis of the breast. However, a well-demarcated, moderately heterogeneous mass with echogenic walls on ultrasound is not consistent with fat necrosis of the breast, which is more likely to manifest as a fluid-filled oil cyst with coarse rim calcifications.
questions.hint: This patient likely has a benign breast lesion commonly seen in women who are lactating.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to your clinic with intermittent episodes of diffuse, bilateral breast pain over the past 4 months. The episodes occur every 4–5 weeks. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no medications. Her menses are regular, with her last menstrual period 3 weeks ago. She plays on a local basketball team and practices 3–4 times per week. Vital signs are normal. On examination, her breasts are tender, soft, and symmetric, with no palpable masses, skin changes, or nipple discharge. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide reassurance and prescribe oral ibuprofen.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rest and heat application can be effective for the treatment of extramammary musculoskeletal chest pain. This patient plays sports regularly, which can cause musculoskeletal injuries. However, extramammary chest pain does not typically follow a cyclical pattern and usually does not affect both sides equally. This patient's presentation is consistent with cyclical mastalgia, for which heat application can be helpful but rest or activity restriction is not required.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral tamoxifen is the preferred second-line therapy for cyclical mastalgia and should be considered if breast pain persists after 6 months of first-line treatment. This patient has not received any treatment yet, making a different step more appropriate at this time.

C) CORRECT:

Cyclical mastalgia is typically caused by hormonal fluctuations during the menstrual cycle. The initial step in the management of cyclical mastalgia is to provide reassurance (to reduce patient anxiety about a potential malignancy), provide topical or oral analgesics (e.g., diclofenac gel, oral ibuprofen or acetaminophen), and recommend supportive measures such as cold or warm compresses and support garments (e.g., well-fitting, soft bras). For patients who are on oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy, discontinuing or reducing the dose of these medications can be trialed. Breast imaging (ultrasound or mammography) is not routinely indicated in cyclical mastalgia. In patients with severe cyclical mastalgia that persists after 6 months of first-line therapy, tamoxifen should be considered as a second-line treatment.

See “Overview of mastalgia” table.

Key learning point: Cyclical mastalgia is managed initially with reassurance, supportive measures, and analgesics; imaging or hormonal therapy is reserved for persistent or suspicious cases.

D) INCORRECT:

For a patient with mastalgia, breast imaging (ultrasound or mammography) is indicated if there are features that raise suspicion for malignancy (e.g., focal noncyclical mastalgia, breast mass, skin changes, nipple discharge). This patient has a normal clinical breast examination and cyclical mastalgia, for which breast imaging is not routinely indicated. Furthermore, for a patient < 30 years of age, ultrasound, rather than mammography, is the preferred modality for breast imaging as the higher breast tissue density makes detection of breast abnormalities with mammography more difficult.

E) INCORRECT:

Reducing the dose of or discontinuing, rather than starting, combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) can be trialed in patients with cyclical mastalgia. Some patients experience symptom relief after reducing the dose of estrogen.
questions.hint: Diffuse, bilateral breast pain that occurs at regular intervals is consistent with cyclical mastalgia.
